channel.title: Nature Materials
channel.description: Nature Materials is a multidisciplinary journal aimed at bringing together cutting-edge research across the entire spectrum of materials science and technology. Nature Materials covers all applied and fundamental aspects of the synthesis/processing, structure/composition, properties and performance of materials. Nature Materials provides a forum for the development of a common identity among materials scientists while encouraging researchers to cross established subdisciplinary lines. To achieve this, Nature Materials takes an interdisciplinary, integrated and balanced approach to all areas of materials research while fostering the exchange of ideas between scientists involved in different communities.

item.title: Measuring nanoscale mechanics
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 31 October 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02395-4

Measuring nanoscale mechanics
item.dc:title: Measuring nanoscale mechanics
item.dc:creator: Stacey M. Chin

item.title: Geometry-driven polar antiferromagnetic metallicity in a double-layered perovskite cobaltate
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 28 October 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02392-7

Cobalt ions in different sublayers of the double-layered Ruddlesden–Popper perovskite Sr3Co2O7 are found to develop inequivalent ionic displacements, geometrically generating a polar state while preserving metallic conductivity and exhibiting antiferromagnetism.
item.dc:title: Geometry-driven polar antiferromagnetic metallicity in a double-layered perovskite cobaltate

item.title: Polarization-driven spontaneous scrolling of two-dimensional materials
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 24 October 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02376-7

Rolling two-dimensional materials into one-dimensional nanoscrolls unlocks tunable emergent properties; however, existing methods rely on external forces. Now, intrinsically driven scrolling in polar two-dimensional materials mediated by out-of-plane electric polarization is reported, establishing a platform for the design of functional nanoscrolls.
item.dc:title: Polarization-driven spontaneous scrolling of two-dimensional materials

item.title: Unisensory processing of interleaving memristive nanowires enabling multimodal sensing at human-scale resolution
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 24 October 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02373-w

A fast and scalable sensor using a core–shell nanowire network is reported to capture multimodal information through memristive switching.
item.dc:title: Unisensory processing of interleaving memristive nanowires enabling multimodal sensing at human-scale resolution
item.dc:creator: Kyun Kyu Kim
Junhyuk Bang
Munju Kim
Juho Jeong
Inho Ha
Seung Hwan Ko
